speaker.details: Sebastian begleitet die IT-Industrie bereits seit mehr als zwei Jahrzehnten; als Redakteur, als Beobachter, als Zuhörer. Er verantwortet bei Software & Support Media den Bereich Content und leitet die Teams, die redaktionell für Magazine und Konferenzen auf der Plattform entwickler.de bzw. devm.io verantwortlich sind .

Davy Kenis is a (technical) agile devops coach who specializes in helping companies enhance organisational effictiveness through structured approaches. With over 15 years of experience Davy has worked across various of domains: Telecom, Banking, Logistics, B2B,… in both national and international organisations. With a background in software development, he began his carreer as a test exert, driven by a passion for integrating quality into every aspect of the Software Development Lifecycle. Today Davy mainly focuses on empowering organisations and teams to achieve their goals and unlock their full potentials while delivering high-end quality products and services. With his experience as agile coach, product owner/manager, devops consultant and qa export he is able to give a different perspective on software development. Davy has discovered a passion for public speaking. He views it as a mission to inspire and engage an audience, with a blend of education and entertainment.

As a seasoned DevOps engineer, I pride myself on ensuring the quality of products by drawing parallels between complex issues and simpler, everyday scenarios. This unique approach aids my team and me in delivering value, ensuring that our products are not only built correctly but also offer the right functionalities.

Als das Cloud Computing in den späten 2000er Jahren aufkam, erkannte Marius dessen enormes Potenzial. Von da an verfolgte er die Entwicklung der Cloud-Technologien mit Schwerpunkt auf IaaS, PaaS oder hybriden Architekturen und insbesondere auf Azure, der Cloud von Microsoft. Sein gemischter Hintergrund als Entwickler und IT-Fachmann ermöglicht es ihm, sich als Berater für komplexe Anwendungs- oder Infrastrukturprojekte zu positionieren und Teams bei der Entwicklung, Verwaltung und Architektur von Cloud-Lösungen zu schulen und zu coachen. Als Azure MVP und Advisor arbeitet Marius Zaharia eng mit den Microsoft-Produktteams zusammen und gibt Feedback und Einblicke in verschiedene Azure-Dienste und -Technologien. Marius ist ein leidenschaftliches und proaktives Mitglied der globalen Azure-Community, Community Manager der AZUG FR (Azure User Group France), Organisator und Redner bei Cloud-bezogenen Veranstaltungen und Konferenzen, Blog-Autor und - in seiner begrenzten Freizeit - Gitarrist und Sänger.

Almudena is of a mathematical vocation and has been dedicated to performance engineering for 18 years. Almudena has worked on projects with high traffic and high availability from online television platforms, job portals, security proxies, and now a European retailer. For 15 years, she has been actively involved in the dissemination of DevOps and performance culture in Spain. She is also an activist for the integration of female talent in STEM as an ambassador for Girls in Tech Spain.

Garima is thought leader for broad range of technologies, spanning from DevOps, Cloud, Data Science & AI technologies. She is the founder of DevOps Community of Practice, Canada. She leads the ambassador program for Continuous Delivery Foundation. She has over two decades of experience leading large-scale multi-billion dollar R&D initiatives with a variety of teams and has helped them adapt technologies, achieve explosive market growth for new products in Telco domain. Furthermore, she has delivered many international conference talks, written several technical blog posts, and published white papers. - Author (Book) - Strategizing Continuous Delivery in the Cloud - Author (Book) – CI/CD Design Patterns

DevOps Institute Ambassador. CD.Foundation Ambassador. AWS Community Builder. Engineer, leader, mentor, speaker. My focus is on CALMS. I am building better understanding of DevOps as driver for the organization. I am devoted to Serverless and CI/CD. I authored the framework for design the CI/CD: https://www.cicd.run/ Host of Last Week In IT and DevOps In Agile Way podcasts.

Thomas Kruse started to work as a freelance consultant in 1998. Today he works for trion development GmbH offering services as architect, trainer and coach for projects based on Cloud and Java technology. His main focus lies on Java based web applications, Kubernetes and Cloud.
In his spare time he is engaged in OpenSource projects and organizes the Java user group in Muenster, Germany.

Rob Richardson is a software craftsman building web properties in ASP.NET and Node, React and Vue. He’s a Microsoft MVP, published author, frequent speaker at conferences, user groups, and community events, and a diligent teacher and student of high quality software development. You can find this and other talks on https://robrich.org/presentations and follow him on twitter at @rob_rich.

Yadhu is a technologist at Sahaj, where he addresses unique technology and business challenges. Based in London, UK, he is skilled in TypeScript, Java Spring Boot, Python, and AWS. His work primarily involves implementing Infrastructure as Code, utilizing tools like Helm, Crossplane, Terraform, and Kubernetes to develop dependable systems. Beyond his professional life, Yadhu enjoys cooking, gardening, hiking, and attending theater and plays.

My career has taken me through a diverse journey, spanning roles that include full-stack developer, business analyst, IT manager, and now thriving in cybersecurity. Throughout this journey, my deep passion for technology has remained a constant driving force. For me, security resembles solving a 10,000-piece puzzle that's been turned upside down. You understand the end goal, yet you're uncertain about where each piece belongs. Achieving this requires close collaboration with developers, business stakeholders, and others, necessitating me to consistently bridge different disciplines within technology. Whether it's simplifying intricate development concepts for security and business professionals or vice versa, every piece added brings us nearer to the solution. This challenge deeply motivates me. I approach my work with a clear focus on prioritizing people first, followed by refining processes, and then utilizing technology to enhance these efforts.

Kris Buytaert is a long time Devops and Open Source Expert and Engineering Leader. He's one of instigators of the devops movement, working for Inuits.eu / o11y.eu He started more than one conference series and lost count on how many times he spoke at other events. He spends most of his time working on bridging the gap between developers and operations , while warning people not to make the mistakes he made. He builds infrastructures that can survive the 10th floor test, or a datacenter fire, while actively promoting the devops idea ! He hasn't blogged for a while but people still point out the title of his blog. Titled "Everything is a Freaking DNS Problem" ,it can be found at http://www.krisbuytaert.be/blog/

John Willis has worked in the IT management for over 40 years. He is researching DevOps, DevSecOps, IT risk, modern governance, and audit compliance. Previously, he was an Evangelist at Docker Inc., VP of Solutions for Socketplane (sold to Docker) and Enstratius (sold to Dell), and VP of Training & Services at Opscode, where he formalized the training, evangelism, and professional services functions at the firm. Additionally, Willis founded Gulf Breeze Software, an award-winning IBM business partner specializing in Tivoli technology deployment. As an author, Willis has written six IBM Redbooks on enterprise systems management and four books for IT Revolution, including the DevOps Handbook. He is working on his latest book, The Operational History of Generative AI.

Ivett Ördög is a public speaker and the creator of Lean Poker, a gamified DevOps training tool that teaches agile, lean and continuous deployment practices to developers. She is based in Bavaria, Germany and has over 25 years of professional experience in software development and 15 in leadership. She is passionate about innovation, collaboration and learning, and enjoys sharing her knowledge and insights with others.

Daniel Bryant is a platform engineer and Head of PMM at Syntasso. His technical expertise focuses on ‘DevOps’ tooling, cloud/container platforms, and microservice implementations. Daniel is a long-time coder, platform engineer, and Java Champion who contributes to several open source projects. He also writes for InfoQ, O’Reilly, and The New Stack and regularly presents at international conferences such as KubeCon, QCon, and JavaOne. In his copious amounts of free time, he enjoys running, reading, and travelling.

Jon Dodkins is an engineering leader with a deep interest in Developer Experience, DevOps and Platform Engineering strategy. His career has spanned advising early-stage startups in lean product development, to deploying large-scale SRE operating models and cloud-native platform engineering. Jon’s focus is on building software and engineering orgs that scale by considering developer-first efficiencies that maximise delivery performance, without sacrificing quality. He’s also passionate about technology operating frameworks for leadership levels that enable success across all stages in the software development lifecycle. Jon has led engineering and platform teams in energy, health-tech and is now Head of Technical Solutions at software development partners Headforwards.

John Wood, the Senior Regional Sales Manager at Contrast Security, has been working at the forefront of Application Security since 2006 where he was responsible for establishing one of the early SAST vendors in the United Kingdom and Europe. Areas of special interest are SAMM and the advanced use of measurement and metrics to assist CISOs in running successful programs of work.
He is a frequent speaker at industry events, often using allegories from subjects as diverse as Ethology and Behavioural Economics to explain the route to successful Application Security. A graduate of Portsmouth University and Queensland University of Technology he holds degrees in Economic History, Entrepreneurship and Technology Management.

Pablo García is an experienced Cloud DevOps Engineer with a strong expertise in cloud hyperscalers and data engineering. Currently working at Swisscom, he is participating in projects which involve GenAI applications in AWS Bedrock, creating assistants to streamline business information retrieval. As an enthusiast of ETL pipelines design, he has successfully architected efficient data pipelines for large volumes, executed proof-of-concepts and demos for wide variety of audiences.

As the Head of SecOps for the largest greenfield technology transformation project in Europe, Lianne is building a leading edge security team from scratch to meet the needs of a modern retail organisation while empowering her team to think innovatively to create new standards in best practices. Drawing upon her expertise as a cyber-anthropologist (through her consultancy, The Anthrosecurist), her practical experience as a security-focused software developer and as a security practitioner; Lianne combines the human and the technical aspects of security to evangelise a cultural security transformation. In 2023 she won ‘Cyber Personality of the Year’ in The Real Cyber Awards. You can listen to Lianne talk about her human-centric approach every Thursday on her award-winning technology podcast Compromising Positions, in which she interviews non-cybersecurity people from the world of anthropology, psychology and behavioural science about cybersecurity culture. She is doing a Masters in AI and Data Science in 2024.

Mark ist ein Forscher, Politikanalyst und Autor, der seit über 30 Jahren in den Bereichen Datensysteme und APIs, öffentliche Gesundheit, Stadtplanung und Gleichstellungspolitik arbeitet. Er ist der Hauptautor des API-Rahmens der Europäischen Kommission für die digitale Verwaltung, hat die Weltbank bei der Ermöglichung von API-Technologien für die finanzielle Eingliederung beraten und vor kurzem für die Weltgesundheitsorganisation Forschungen über globale Best Practices für die Datenverwaltung und für das Open Data Institute über den Reifegrad von Ökosystemen für Gesundheitsdaten in Europa abgeschlossen.

With a strong foundation in network security orchestration and site reliability engineering, I am dedicated to advancing modern infrastructure practices through the adoption of cutting-edge SRE principles. My expertise spans GitOps, Go, C++, Python programming, and Linux troubleshooting, enabling me to drive innovation and foster a culture of continuous improvement.
Throughout my career, I have contributed to modernizing legacy systems, building automated testing platforms, and designing efficient CI/CD pipelines. My proficiency with tools like Docker, Ansible, and Jenkins has supported high-quality software delivery and the seamless integration of automation into development workflows.

Neil is a seasoned technologist, dynamic speaker, and moderator with an unwavering passion for developer experience, engineering innovation, automation, and AI. With a proven track record in driving digital transformation and accelerating DevOps and platform engineering initiatives across industries such as finance and healthcare, Neil stands at the forefront of shaping the future of software engineering. A visionary thinker, Neil transforms intricate technical challenges into clear, actionable insights. He crafts scalable solutions that simplify complexity and significantly enhance the developer experience. As a senior Product evangelist at Fujitsu UVANCE—a global consulting and transformation firm, Neil leads projects that seamlessly integrate cutting-edge technology, automation, and developer support, setting new benchmarks for sustainable engineering. Neil has delivered acclaimed talks including DevOps' Dirty Little Secret and Inertia vs Innovation.

Eric Paulsen is the Field CTO at Coder.com, an open-source, self-hosted cloud development environment platform. He is the Founding Sales Engineer at Coder and leads Developer Experience transformation for customers in highly regulated industries.

Ikenna Nwaiwu ist Hauptberater bei Ikenna Consulting, wo er Unternehmen dabei hilft, den Umsatz ihrer API-fähigen Produkte zu steigern und ihre Kosten zu senken, indem sie ihren API-Wertstrom transformieren. Er ist der Autor von "Automating API Delivery: APIOps mit OpenAPI". Zuvor hat er bei 10x Banking, Bank of America, UBS und Thoughtworks gearbeitet.

Billy Thompson leads DevOps and Platform Engineering solutioning for Office of the CTO, Akamai Cloud Computing. As a passionate open source evangelist, he enables customers to build and implement portable/cloud-agnostic workloads at scale. In other words, Billy is just having fun! He is also a longtime Arch Linux user and vegan, and never knows which to tell people first! Outside of work he dabbles with graphic design, film, and Techno music production.

Chief Architect at Akamai. Previously a founder and CTO of Ondat (formerly StorageOS), building software defined solutions for cloud native environments. Alex is also a co-chair of the CNCF Storage TAG. Before embarking on the startup adventure he spent over 25 years engineering infrastructure platforms for companies like Nomura and Goldman Sachs.

Chris has been working with Kubernetes since pre 1.0 when it was the Beta for OpenShift version 3 at Red Hat. Since then he has moved, via VMware and Tanzu, to Akamai (via Ondat) as a Senior Product Architect, helping to design and deliver cloud scale technologies. Outside of work, Chris plays field hockey, loves cycling around Hampshire and is Dad to his kids, one of whom is about to become taller than he is.

Aurélien SVEVI is a seasoned application security expert with seven years of experience helping enterprises bridge the gap between security and development. Based in France, he has a proven track record of making application security not just effective, but truly engaging for teams. With deep technical expertise and a knack for simplifying complex security challenges, Aurélien ensures that security becomes an enabler—not a blocker—for development teams. His passion for DevSecOps, team integration, and security education empowers organisations to build resilient, secure applications with confidence.

Taylor Mowat is a standout Application Security Engineer with extensive experience in cybersecurity. Taylor has made significant contributions, building deliberately vulnerable applications and writing cybersecurity content for an EdTech start-up. He was instrumental in introducing an innovative new application security training product to teach developers about secure coding and DevSecOps. Now, Taylor works as a Solutions Engineer at Contrast Security and evangelises Runtime Security as the next generation of application security testing and a safer and more effective alternative to traditional testing.

James Fenton is Senior Regional Sales Manager UK at Contrast Security, with 20+ years in enterprise IT security sales. He specialises in application security, DevSecOps, and CI/CD integrations, helping organisations protect applications from modern threats. Previously at Synopsys, he led security adoption across EMEA. A frequent OWASP and ISSA contributor, James brings deep expertise in bridging security and development.

Helen leads the ambassador program at PeopleCert for DevOps Institute, ITIL, and PRINCE2. She is CEO and chair of the Value Stream Management Consortium, co-chair of the OASIS Value Stream Management Interoperability Technical Committee, and chair of the DevNetwork DevOps Advisory Board and provides strategic advisory services to DevOps and VSM industry leaders. Helen is the author of the annual State of VSM Reports from the VSMC and the State of Availability Report from Moogsoft. She is a co-author of the book about DevOps and governance, Investments Unlimited, published by IT Revolution. She is a DevOps editor for InfoQ, and also writes for many other online platforms. Helen hosts the Day-to-Day DevOps webinar series for BrightTalk and speaks on DevOps, AI, and value stream-related topics at industry conferences and corporate events.

Kaushal Vyas is a Product Manager at Bitrise, where he leads the CI and Insights product portfolio. With his entrepreneurial mindset and data-informed approach, Kaushal has become a respected voice in Mobile DevOps, helping organizations transform their delivery pipelines.
Drawing on his multidisciplinary background as an engineer, designer, and MBA graduate, Kaushal brings a holistic perspective to complex mobile development challenges. His expertise spans fintech, streaming video, e-learning, and enterprise SaaS, giving him invaluable insights into the diverse needs of mobile-first organizations. His passion for understanding customer needs has made him instrumental in shaping Bitrise's product strategy.

I'm hugely passionate about technology and technology sales, so it comes as no surprise that I'm heavily involved in both. The fascinating part for me is at the intersection of the two; whereby I'm both hands-on with cutting edge cyber-security tools whilst providing measurable business value to customers.
As an experienced pre-sales leader, I spend a significant amount of time and energy helping to coach, develop and mentor my team to be the best they can be. I'm a firm believer that by helping others to develop and grow, you increase your own effectiveness as a leader by making your team more independent and autonomous.
When I'm not working, you'll find me relaxing and enjoying life with my wife and two children. When I get a spare moment, Im usually doing something attached to my interest in blockchain and Decentralised Finance.

From the early days of build and deployment automation, Shivaji has been transforming software delivery. With a strong background in development and IT operations, he bridges gaps between teams, enabling seamless collaboration and continuous delivery. As a DevOps consultant, Shivaji specializes in automation, CI/CD pipelines, cloud-native architectures, and driving organizational success through innovation. Proficient in tools like Azure DevOps, Kubernetes, and Terraform, he helps businesses adopt scalable, resilient solutions. A passionate advocate for the DevOps community, Shivaji shares insights through events, blogs, and mentoring. Outside work, he explores emerging technologies, enjoys reading, and pursues creative hobbies, reflecting his commitment to lifelong learning and growth.
John Hanby is a Senior Solution Engineer at MuleSoft driving the strategic direction and working with enterprise customers to deliver API led connectivity

Kenneth Okeke is a Senior Solution Engineer at MuleSoft from Salesforce Bridging today’s systems with tomorrow’s intelligence—helping organisations deliver truly autonomous AI agents with integration and Automation

Bill Emmett is the Senior Director of Technical Product Marketing at Cribl. He began his career in IT administration and software development before moving into technical product marketing roles at companies such as Cribl, Splunk, and LogicMonitor. With deep industry experience, Bill understands technical audiences and clearly communicates the value of complex solutions in an authentic and compelling way.

session.name: How Your Culture Shapes Delivery Excellence
session.details: Tech is the easy part; the secret ingredient to achieving delivery excellence lies within the cultural foundation of an organization. In this session, we’ll explore how business and company culture directly impact the quality, speed, employee satisfaction, and sustainability of delivery outcomes. Through real-world examples, we’ll uncover how trust, transparency, and collaboration can empower teams to break down silos and drive meaningful results. Key Takeaways: How to foster a culture that prioritizes continuous learning. The essentials of psychological safety for innovation and resilience. The power of ownership in team and individual performance. This session is designed for everyone—whether you’re leading an organization, guiding a team, or contributing as a team member. Together, we’ll discover how cultivating the right culture can be your most powerful tool for DevOps success.

session.longAbstract:
Agenda


1. Basics of Continuous Delivery for engineering leaders (1 Hour) 

  • We start with an affinity game to assess the state of nation of engineering leaders in audience.

 

  • Introduction to Building Blocks of Continuous Delivery, including planning and preparing for CI/CD at scale, exploring the technical strategy to achieve successful implementation.

 

  • Exploring Engineering leader’s role in continuous Delivery, this session will provide leaders enhanced skills to onboard to continuous delivery into organizations with confidence

 

  • Managing Continuous Delivery Culture by building capacity to align continuous delivery investments into tools, practices and skills needed to create the new business opportunities and scale it.

 

2. Strategizing Continuous Delivery (1 Hour) 

  • Overview of IaC, Pipeline as Code, Branching strategies, practical exercises 

 

  • Introduction of testing strategies, continuous testing is a crucial component of CI/CD pipelines. It ensures that any changes made to the software do not introduce any defects or regression issues. We will discuss various tools and techniques to enhance the test strategy and implementation with practical examples.

 

  • Deep dive into delivery strategies – progressive delivery, canary analysis, deployment Models - On-prem, SaaS, and other hybrid offerings. We will learn about different ways of hosting CI/CD workloads.

 

3. Introduction to Continuous Delivery patterns (45 minutes) 

  • Design patterns can help enforce CI/CD pipelines by providing guidance on how to structure code, manage dependencies, handle errors and perform software testing. The audience will be introduced to design patterns for CI/CD, which are existing implementations often tagged as recurrent solutions

 

4. Use of open source in Continuous Delivery (2 Hour) 

  • We will introduce various tools and techniques to implement CI/CD with open source. Introduction to fastest growing open-source projects in CI/CD space and strategy to integrate them into your pipelines.

 

  • Finding synergies between developer and open source, actively consuming open source with examples with GitHub actions, Helm and many more. Practical exercise to build the pipeline using GitHub Actions.

 

  • Advance hands-on exercises to implement add-on features to CI/CD pipeline with security, exploration of pull requests and decision automation, advanced access Control and implementing Observability.

 

5. Evolve the Continuous Delivery (1 Hour) 

  • Measure the Continuous Delivery by implementing DORA metrics

 

  • Introduction to SBOM toolchain, generation of SBOM, Compliance requirements and assessment frameworks.

 

  • Introduction to machine learning and AI and the potential of generative AI tools.

 


Disclaimer – depending on the knowledge of the audience, practical environment, the organizer of the workshop might decide to take certain topics in more detail than others.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

- Installed Git, GitHub account configured, IDE of choice (code editor). They prepare a short instruction for GitHub account creation, just in case.


On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.
We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Workshop: Strategizing Continuous Delivery for Engineering Leaders
session.details: In this all-day workshop, you will be able to explore Continuous Delivery design patterns. We will start with introduction to the basic building blocks of CI/CD from the conceptual level and further introduce practical aspects of the implementation of various components like IaC, Pipeline as Code, and its integration with open source. This workshop is primarily useful for engineering leaders looking to scale a Continuous Delivery ecosystem with open source. We will cover the basics of Continuous Delivery for engineering leaders (OKRs, Team Structure & Operating Model), strategizing Continuous Delivery, the branching strategy, deployment Strategy, and pipelines & IaC. This workshop will discuss the use of open source in Continuous Delivery and how to evolve Continuous Delivery.

session.longAbstract:
Part 1: Introduction to GitOps (this should be very short as its only theory) – 15’
  1. Understanding GitOps:
    1. Overview of GitOps principles and benefits.
    2. Key concepts: declarative infrastructure, version control, and automated workflows.
    3. Comparing GitOps with traditional CI/CD approaches.
 
Part 2: Setting Up Continuous Integration with GitLab CI (2 hours)
  1. Starting with GitLab CI (demo)
    1. Writing a `Dockerfile` for your application.
    2. Configuring a `.gitlab-ci.yml` file to build and test Docker images.
    3. Pushing Docker images to GitLab Container Registry.
  2. Hands-On Lab:
    1. Participants will set up their own GitLab CI pipeline to build and test a sample application.
    2. Real-time guidance and troubleshooting.
 
Part 3: Install a local K8s cluster using K3d (30’)


Part 4: Automating Continuous Delivery with Flux (30’)
  1. Installing Flux on a Kubernetes Cluster:
    1. Step-by-step installation of Flux on a Kubernetes cluster.
    2. Connecting Flux to a Git repository.
    3. Looking at Kubernetes secrets responsible for the bootstrapping process
    4. Observing GitRepository & Kustomization custom resource definitions (CRDs) and their action
  2. Implementation of Image Automation :
    1. Writing manifests for Image repositoiry, image policy and image update automation
    2. Creation of the necessary CRDs using Kustomize
 
Part 5: Integrating GitLab CI with Flux for GitOps-Driven Deployments (exercises) – 1.5 hours
  1. Linking CI and CD:
    1. Creating a deployment manifest for the sample application
    2. Updating Kubernetes manifests with new Docker image tags.
    3. Committing and pushing changes to the Git repository monitored by Flux.
  2. Check self healing behaviour: Simulate a failure by manually editing the deployment or deleting resources
  3. Scale up your application deployments without any change on the cluster manually
Part 6: Wrap up (5')
Best practices with Gitops CICD

Part 7: Questions (10')

Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:

  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.
We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Workshop: Empowering SRE with GitOps: Automate Kubernetes deployments with Gitlab CI and Flux CD
session.details: In this hands-on technical workshop, attendees will dive into the world of GitOps, learning how to integrate GitLab CI/CD with Flux to create a seamless and automated continuous delivery pipeline for Kubernetes applications. Participants will gain practical experience in setting up and configuring both GitLab CI for continuous integration and Flux for continuous delivery, using Git as the single source of truth for declarative infrastructure and application management.

session.name: Royal Flush in DevSecOps – Unlocking the Secrets of a Winning Strategy
session.details: Ready to win at DevSecOps? In this high-stakes session, Mike will share how to stack the deck in your favor by integrating the right tools and strategies, giving you a competitive edge. You’ll learn the five essential layers that will ensure your DevSecOps approach is designed for success! Just like in poker, every move counts. With our methods, you’ll always stay one step ahead. Don’t leave Security to chance! Join Mike to discover how to play your cards right, leveraging automation, effective culture, the right tools and continuous improvement—plus much more! Let’s ensure you’re always holding the winning hand!

session.name: Intelligent Infrastructure: The AI at the Service of the Cloud
session.details: Intelligent Infrastructure is a rapidly evolving concept that leverages advanced technologies to optimize the performance, reliability, and security of IT systems. By incorporating predictive maintenance, intelligent assistance, and other innovative approaches, organizations can enhance their infrastructure's quality of service, ultimately benefiting the applications that rely on it. In this session, we will study principles like AIOps, Autonomous Agents, and others, to enhance the reliability, performance, and security of our Cloud infrastructure. We will also learn from the Cloud Service Providers (Azure, AWS) how they implement the Intelligent Infrastructure in the Public Cloud, and how we can leverage their experience and technologies for the benefit of our applications.

session.name: GitOps: The Why and How
session.details: In the context of Kubernetes continuous integration can be implemented using established tools like Jenkins or Bamboo. But Kubernetes opens up the opportunity to do even more: Provide stakeholders with isolated environments for continuous delivery. This is the foundation for fast feedback and iteration. Traditional tools can be used for continuous delivery as well, but is that process optimal? Which security concerns need to be considered? See for yourself how GitOps works and why it provides benefits for your organization. You will see how ArgoCD can be used to implement GitOps and how you get better insights into your projects compared to using a simple CI server.

session.name: Streamline Your DevOps: Managing and Shipping Infrastructure and Services in a Single Git Flow
session.details:
One of the biggest pain points for developers when shipping features quickly is jumping through multiple hurdles and configuration changes to ensure that the updated or additional infrastructure for the new feature is ready.

This makes a 3 point become a 5 point, adds additional points of failures to take care of and more than anything, creates another part of code that needs to be known and maintained.

What if I could show you how it’s possible to have a single Git push and one unified service and infrastructure definition? This approach would allow infrastructure updates or additions and feature deployments in one step, while also enabling rollback capability and reducing the amount of code to maintain. Join me in this talk to explore how.

session.name: 10 Reasons Why We Can’t Do Continuous Delivery
session.details: Every time you walk in to a new organisation there is typically some level of resistance against moving from yearly or quarterly releases to a continuous delivery mindset. This talk will debunk a number of myths on why you seemingly can't do Continuous Delivery. 15+ years of working with different types of organisations on this topic brought me recipes on how to counter these invalid reasons I will cover both cultural and more technical challenges. After this talk you will have a better understanding on what it means to adopt Continuous Delivery, and why you are already too late in doing so.

session.workshopRequirements:
For this workshop you'll need to prepare:

1.    Install Terraform CLI
2.    Install AWS CLI
3.    Optional: Install Node.js
4.    Optional: Install Docker Desktop
5.    An AWS account with root priviledges
session.longAbstract:
In this workshop we look at Terraform, the most popular Infrastructure-as-code platform. We'll use AWS as a target environment, and deploy sample infrastructure. 

We'll deploy:

- DynamoDB database
- Lambda code function
- API Gateway
- A container running in Fargate ECS
- An Application Load Balancer (ALB)
- All the necessary configuration for every piece
- Roles, policies, and permissions for each

Along the way we'll learn:

- The value of Infrastructure as Code
- The pain of Click-ops
- Terraform syntax and popular commands
- How to run Terraform in a DevOps pipeline

Terraform is definitely an investment, but it's an investment that pays you back every time you need to make a change to any environment or recover from disaster. You can get started or level-up with Terraform on AWS today.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:

Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.

For this workshop you'll need to prepare:

1.    Install Terraform CLI
2.    Install AWS CLI
3.    Optional: Install Node.js
4.    Optional: Install Docker Desktop
5.    An AWS account with root priviledges

We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Terraform Hands-on Workshop
session.details:
You've clicked through the cloud portal and deployed the infrastructure. But what about the next environment? Can you click exactly the same buttons in the same order? And what about when the needs change? Can you evolve all the environments identically? Click-ops can only get you so far.

Infrastructure-as-Code allows you to create consistent, durable, codified environments the same way you make durable and consistent applications. Once the code is in place, you can efficiently spin up another environment that is identical in every way. And when a change occurs, the same code updates the next system identically and consistently.

session.name: Lessons from 10 years of Platform Engineering
session.details: Platform Engineering is the new hype on the block. But we've been doing this for some 10 years, we just didn't call it Platform Engineering. We provided self service enabled platforms with guardrails for development teams to consume. Some did successfully, some didn't ... This talk will help you learn from the mistakes we made along the road and but also from the successes. Spoiler: it's mostly about communication.

session.name: Ready, (Change)set, (Ar)go: How GitOps Empowers Schiphol Airport’s GitOps Journey
session.details:
With over 60 million travelers per year, Schiphol needs a reliable way for deploying new software. To achieve this at a cost effective, efficient and simple way, Schiphol created a fully automated GitOps workflow in Github. Join me in exploring Schiphols' GitOps journey.

You will learn how Schiphol uses ArgoCD, GitHub, Changeset, Helm, and Release Please to create a deployment pipeline for multi-team DevOps. This session will show how to use Changesets for application versioning, ArgoCD Image Updater for automated application updates, and Release Please for managing Helm release versions, ensuring consistency and traceability across deployment environments. Through this session, you will gain practical knowledge on implementing GitOps principles, including version control, release automation, and deployment best practices in Kubernetes. The tutorial highlights Schiphol’s solutions to common scaling and coordination challenges within a large CI/CD environment, providing a real-world case study that you can apply in your own teams. This session is designed for DevOps engineers, CI/CD specialists, and platform architects who aim to unify development and operations workflows, reduce manual processes, and promote consistent, error-free deployments.

session.name: The One About Titanic and Metrics, or Why Jack Fit in the Log
session.details:
Welcome to this talk on the cardinality of metrics in Kubernetes clusters. Today, we will explore what cardinality is, why it is important in the context of observability, and how to manage it efficiently in a Kubernetes environment.

What is Cardinality?

Importance in Kubernetes

Common Challenges:

1. Time Series Explosion 2. Storage and Performance 3. Cost

Strategies for Managing Cardinality:

1. Label Prudently 2. Adjust Scraping and Retention 3. Use Aggregation Tools

Conclusion: Managing the cardinality of metrics is crucial to maintaining an efficient and scalable monitoring system in Kubernetes. By adopting good practices in metric labeling and using appropriate tools, we can ensure that our monitoring system remains robust and cost-effective.

session.name: Mastering Kubernetes Operators: From Concept to Custom Controllers
session.details: In the rapidly evolving world of cloud-native applications, Kubernetes Operators have emerged as a powerful tool to extend the Kubernetes API and automate complex application lifecycles. This session will dive into the practical aspects of building your own Kubernetes Operator from scratch. We’ll explore the core concepts, walk through real-world examples, and highlight best practices to ensure your Operators are robust and maintainable. Whether you're a seasoned Kubernetes user or just getting started, you'll leave with the knowledge and confidence to start developing custom Operators tailored to your needs.

session.longAbstract:
Detailed Agenda:

1. Introduction to AI in DevOps and DevSecOps

  • Brief overview of the current state of AI in software development.
  • The emergence of AI tools and their potential.

2. Deep Dive into Generative AI Tools

  • Exploring the capabilities of LLMs, LangChain, and LangSmith in software delivery.
  • Case studies showcasing their impact and benefits in real-world scenarios.

3. Integrating AI into DevOps and DevSecOps

  • Strategies for effectively incorporating AI tools in CI/CD pipelines.
  • Enhancing security and efficiency through AI-driven solutions.
  • Addressing the challenges and considerations in implementation.

4. Future Trends and Closing Thoughts

  • Discussing the future trajectory of AI in DevOps and DevSecOps.
  • Encouraging proactive adoption and ongoing learning.


Outcomes:

  • Attendees will gain a comprehensive understanding of the role and potential of AI in enhancing DevOps and DevSecOps.
  • Insights into practical strategies for integrating AI into existing workflows.
  • Awareness of the challenges and best practices in AI adoption in software development.


Conclusion: 

This talk is an opportunity for professionals in the software development and IT security fields to understand and embrace the transformative potential of AI in their domains. Join us to explore cutting-edge AI-driven DevOps and DevSecOps innovations!
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.
We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Workshop: Rethinking DevOps and DevSecOps with Generative AI: Insights and Innovations
session.details: This workshop talk is designed to provide insights into the revolutionary impact of generative AI tools on DevOps and DevSecOps. The presentation will explore how advanced AI technologies like Large Language Models (LLMs), LangChain, LangSmith, and vector databases (RAGs) transform the software delivery and security landscape.

session.name: I Implemented Game of Life 100+ Times! Let’s Explore the 3 Most Interesting Takes
session.details: Explore a mind-bending feature of functional programming, how you can easily get started with GPU programming, and learn about underappreciated SQL features that you didn't know you needed. Having facilitated code retreats for years, I’ve witnessed a myriad of solutions to a single, seemingly straightforward problem: Conway’s Game of Life. While varying constraints often lead to different approaches, the most intriguing aspect lies in the valuable lessons these solutions impart, shaping our programming practices for years to come. Join me as we delve into three distinct implementations of this captivating problem. If you join me for this session, you'll have 3 new tools under your belt to write code that impresses your colleagues.

session.name: Service Mess to Service Mesh
session.details: In our quest to secure all the things, do we jump in too quickly? We'll use Istio and Linkerd as example service meshes, and look at the features we would expect from a service mesh. We'll dive into the day-1 experience with both Istio and Linkerd, and some advanced scenarios of using the service mesh. We'll compare this to border security with an app gateway, and compare and contrast the security features, complexities, and implementation costs. You'll leave with a concrete understanding of the benefits and tradeoffs you get when you pull in a service mesh, and be ready to justify the investment.

session.name: Platform Engineering for Software Developers and Architects
session.details: Building on my KubeCon EU 2022 talk, "From Kubernetes to PaaS to... err, what's next", I'll introduce the topic of platform engineering through the lens of a software developer and architect. My primary goal is for developers to understand "what good looks like" with a successful platform build and help them understand how a platform can influence the SDLC (for better or worse!) Key takeaways from the session: - Explore how platform architecture influences software architecture and vice versa - Learn why the principles of coupling and cohesion apply to platform components (and configuration) in the same way as they do with software components - Understand what to expect from an effective platform, including how applications are built, shipped, and run - Learn about key platform metrics grounded in developer experience frameworks such as DORA, SPACE, and DevEx

session.workshopRequirements:
• A working knowledge of Git as a version control system and comfort with the command line is highly recommended.
  • Please bring your own laptop equipped with a web browser and git tools to fully engage in the practical exercises.
  • For those who prefer to use their own machine instead of a workshop cluster, please prepare Docker Desktop or another local Kubernetes setup.
session.longAbstract:
Day 2

1.  Ingress

  • Many APIs and web applications are based on the HTTP protocol. With the Kubernetes ingress concept you will manage the access efficiently.
  • With these elements we look into running more complex applications or microbased services

2. Volumes and configuration

  • Kubernetes provides various ways to handle configuration and secret data
  • We will work with config maps, secrets and how they can be used for pods

3. Deployments

  • One concept with high abstraction level is the Kubernetes Deployment
  • We will use it to manage multiple versions of our application and to roll out updates without any downtime

4.  Persistence

  • We need to persist our state outside of a pod to preserve it in case of planned updates or even failures
  • We will lean how persistent volumes and persistent volume claims work
  • With storage classes we can provide different kinds of storage in a well defined manner

Depending on the time left we will discuss your use cases and questions to ensure that you have a solid understanding and are ready to start with Kubernetes for your projects.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear bootcamp participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.
We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: 2 Days Kubernetes Bootcamp: Becoming a Kubernetes Master - From Clusters to Advanced Deployments - Day 2
session.details:
This compact two-day bootcamp is designed to provide you with an in-depth understanding of Kubernetes. You will start with fundamental concepts and then progress to advanced topics such as volumes, ConfigMaps, Secrets, init-containers, Deployments, and persistence.

Through hands-on labs, you will gain practical experience in deploying and managing applications in a Kubernetes cluster.

By the end of the bootcamp, you will have a solid grasp of Kubernetes architecture and operations. This will enable you to deploy, access, and manage applications efficiently.

You will be well-prepared to work with both cloud-based and on-premises Kubernetes solutions and engage in informed discussions about Kubernetes-based architectures with your peers.

This workshop is ideal for developers who are already familiar with Docker or similar container technologies and are eager to dive into Kubernetes.

session.workshopRequirements:
• A working knowledge of Git as a version control system and comfort with the command line is highly recommended.
  • Please bring your own laptop equipped with a web browser and git tools to fully engage in the practical exercises.
  • For those who prefer to use their own machine instead of a workshop cluster, please prepare Docker Desktop or another local Kubernetes setup.
session.longAbstract:
Day 1

1.  Getting a cluster

  • You will be provided with different options to get a cluster in order to participate in all Kubernetes practice labs
  • Every participant will have the option to use a web based workshop cluster which is especially suitable for participants with enterprise managed notebooks
  • A local cluster with minikube or Docker Desktop is a good way for revisiting the workshop labs later on
  • We will also look into various tools that make working with Kubernetes eaier

2. Accessing your cluster

  • Security is important, so no cluster can be accessed without authentication and authorization
  • How that is implemented in Kubernetes lays a good foundation to handle multiple clusters in parallel

3. Building application images

  • Kubernetes uses container images to provide workload for the cluster
  • You will build your own images using Docker and Dockerfiles
  • We will use these images in the cluster later on to show various important operational aspects
  • Images are distributed using container registries

4. Fundamental Kubernetes concepts

  • We will understand how Kubernetes is organized using namespaces
  • Our first workload will be a simple pod to avoid unnecessary complexity
  • Important elements of the architecture of Kubernetes like etcd, controller manager, scheduler, api server and kubelet will be visited in detail
  • We will learn how to interact with network applications inside Kubernes
  • ... and how to access them from outside the cluster
  • For diagnosis we will run interactive containers inside the cluster

5. Running your applications

  • Now it is time to run our own applications which is a good opportunity to quickly revisit the basics
  • We use the container image we built earlier and even scale it to multiple relicas which leads to the concept of replica sets
  • Using healthcheck probes we will ensure that our customers will only reach healthy instances

6. Using Kubernetes resources

  • Kubernetes is API centric and with our freshly acquired understanding of the architecture and building blocks we are well prepared to dive into the Kubernetes API in more detail
  • You will learn how to manage the configuration of your application using YAML manifests and how to work with them
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:

  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.
We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: 2 Days Kubernetes Bootcamp: Becoming a Kubernetes Master - From Clusters to Advanced Deployments - Day 1
session.details:
This compact two-day bootcamp is designed to provide you with an in-depth understanding of Kubernetes. You will start with fundamental concepts and then progress to advanced topics such as volumes, ConfigMaps, Secrets, init-containers, Deployments, and persistence.

Through hands-on labs, you will gain practical experience in deploying and managing applications in a Kubernetes cluster.

By the end of the bootcamp, you will have a solid grasp of Kubernetes architecture and operations. This will enable you to deploy, access, and manage applications efficiently.

You will be well-prepared to work with both cloud-based and on-premises Kubernetes solutions and engage in informed discussions about Kubernetes-based architectures with your peers.

This workshop is ideal for developers who are already familiar with Docker or similar container technologies and are eager to dive into Kubernetes.

session.name: Learning from History: The Past as a Compass for Systems Engineers in the Age of AI
session.details:
The evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) provides a compelling narrative of innovation and cautionary lessons. Drawing on the themes explored in Rebels of Reason, a new book by John Willis, this presentation emphasizes the critical importance of historical context for systems engineers navigating AI's rapid advancements. From the mechanical wonders of the Industrial Age to Turing’s computational breakthroughs and Frank Rosenblatt's early neural network experiments, the story of AI is a testament to the ingenuity and persistent challenges that shape technological progress.


Understanding these milestones offers systems engineers a foundation to anticipate future challenges, including ethical considerations, societal impact, and technological limitations. By reflecting on the successes and missteps of AI pioneers, engineers can draw valuable insights to balance innovation with responsibility. This presentation underscores that the road forward is guided by the lessons of the past—lessons that advocate for cautious optimism, interdisciplinary collaboration, and a commitment to ethical innovation in creating systems that truly serve humanity.


This talk is essential for those seeking to harness AI's potential while mitigating its risks. It ensures that the past informs strategies to build a more equitable, sustainable, and intelligent future.

session.name: Tackling DevEx Imposter Syndrome or how to evolve your DevOps through Platform Engineering
session.details:
DevOps teams are often perceived as a necessary cost for critical operations. Increasingly, they’re being rebranded as DevEx, with expanded responsibilities but little clarity around goals or strategy. This leaves engineers feeling confused amd even more disconnected from product development and company objectives. The answer lies in fully embracing platform engineering; a transformation that empowers DevOps to operate with the purpose and impact of Product. This shift is an opportunity to break away from the outdated “sysadmins keeping the lights on” mindset and redefine their role as strategic enablers.

I’ll share how Birdie, a healthtech scale-up, reimagined its DevOps function by adopting platform engineering principles. I’ll explore how this approach enables DevOps engineers to think like product engineers- leveraging design, strategy, and user-focused practices - whilst valuing their core expertise.

Attendees will gain actionable insights into aligning people, processes, and technology to foster collaboration, build a strategy and avoid common pitfalls!

session.name: Break
Lunch
Break
Break
Break
Break
Break
Conference Check-in

Lunch
Break
Break
Conference Check-In
Break
Operationalizing AI: Leadership Insights
session.details: The talk is designed for executives and leaders of software technology organization looking into adoption of AI at scale. It will highlight navigating the strategic integration of AI within the organization and dig deeper into skills and competence for AI-savvy software technology organizations. Navigate the operational challenges of adoption and scaling AI, risk management, policy, and governance. This talk will help demystify the operational design of future organizations. Lastly, learn which key DevOps practices remain critical.

session.name: Welcome and opening remarks followed by Are ‘Friends’ Electric? What It Means to Be Human Now and Tomorrow in the Age of AI
session.details:
Welcome and opening remarks by the Program Chair Sebastian Meyen.

followed by this keynote:

In a world where loneliness is an epidemic, could artificial intelligence be the answer? Are ‘friends’ truly electric? In 1979, Gary Numan asked this in his hit song ‘Are ‘Friends’ Electric?’, inspired by Philip K. Dick’s novel “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” and the film “Blade Runner”. In that dystopian future, synthetic humans (replicants) evolved, rebelled, and were pursued by humans. For centuries, we've been fascinated by synthetic ‘friends’—from the 1770 chess-playing Mechanical Turk to today’s AI companions. Once science fiction, electric companions are now a reality. But what does this mean for friendship, love, and humanity? 45 years after Numan's song, have we moved from sci-fi to a new era of human/synth relationships with AI and robotics? Guided by a digital anthropologist specializing in cybersecurity and the digital divide, this talk explores our cultural fascination with replicating human traits and the human condition. It examines how AI and robotics transform our interactions with machines and ourselves. Consider: Culture: Can electric ‘friends’ grasp human culture or just mimic it? Emotions: Are love and creativity exclusive to humans, or can AI experience them? Companionship: Will electric friends reduce or increase social isolation? Dust off Donna Haraway’s ‘A Cyborg Manifesto’ and ponder: Are ‘friends’ truly electric?

session.name: Platform Engineering: Trends and Challenges in 2025
session.details: A look at current trends in platform engineering: creating platform teams, creating shared resources, supporting developer teams, creating and implementing standards, automatic CI/CD delivery pipelines, internal developer portals, data governance, API governance, AI adoption and impacts, and developer productivity metrics. We look at all the key themes and how platform engineering practices are evolving.

session.name: Break
A Brief History of Engineering, 2025
session.details:
From the pioneering trailblazers of mainframe computing and space exploration to the
rockstars who unleashed the internet and cloud revolution—and now to the emergent
Artificial Engineers redefining our digital landscape, software engineering has continuously
evolved through cycles of abstraction, automation, and transformation.
This talk traces the key technologies, methodologies, and cultural shifts that have driven
each era of innovation. We’ll explore how successive layers of abstraction have unlocked
extraordinary digital capabilities, even as they have introduced new complexities and
cognitive challenges. Today, as AI evolves from a supportive copilot to an autonomous
agent capable of digital manifestation, we stand at a pivotal crossroads. Here, the principles
of human ingenuity, machine intelligence, and sustainable engineering must converge.
How can we navigate this seismic shift while ensuring reliability, security, and ethical
governance? Which timeless lessons from our past must we preserve to prevent innovation
from spiraling into chaos? By weaving together historical analysis, technical insights, and
strategic foresight, this talk provides a comprehensive roadmap for understanding our
engineering heritage and steering its future evolution. Join me as we chart the journey from
yesterday’s breakthroughs to tomorrow’s boundless possibilities.

session.name: Evolving API Governance in the Age of AI
session.details: The rise of AI-powered development is fundamentally changing how teams build, manage and consume APIs. This session explores the two-way relationship between AI and API governance: how AI tools can strengthen governance through API design, documentation generation and security scanning, while also examining how traditional API governance must adapt to support AI-powered development workflows. Engineering leaders will learn practical tools and techniques to integrate AI into their API workflows while maintaining security, compliance and developer experience.

session.name: Platform Engineering: Are IDPs Reducing or Repackaging Complexity?
session.details: Like any good trend, the buzz around Platform Engineering has been exciting and painful at the same time. As dust settles, the realities of Internal Developer Platforms (IDPs) become clearer—what they truly solve and what they don’t. While IDPs promise efficiency, the complexity of building and maintaining them often mirrors the intricacies cloud environments they rely on. Are we genuinely reducing toil, or just repackaging it? This talk will address that question with a focus on simplicity and golden path templates. We’ll demonstrate using infrastructure as code (IaC) to programmatically deploy a templated set of CNCF projects to streamline building IDPs that are cloud-native and cloud-agnostic.

session.name: Stateful Superpowers: Explore High Performance and Scalable Stateful Workloads on K8s
session.details:
There is no such thing as a stateless application - All applications need to store state somewhere!

Stateful workloads like databases and key value stores are often deployed outside of K8s, missing out on all the benefits of declarative config, scaling, failover and automatic healing.

In this talk we show how running stateful workloads in K8s is not only performant and scalable but are also resilient, and can facilitate Disaster Recovery.

We will discuss the cloud native ecosystem and discuss use cases like:

●      Running a million RPS on a KV store with TiKV

●      Running scalable, replicated and resilient Postgres databases with CloudNativePG

●      Running analytics & ML on a distributed filesystem with CubeFS

… all in K8s, using K8s features to scale, failover and run day 2 operations.

session.workshopRequirements:
Knowledge Requirements:
  • Basic understanding of software development and web applications.
  • Some experience with DevOps tools (CI/CD pipelines) and application deployment practices is beneficial but not mandatory.
Technical Requirements:
  • Laptop required.
  •  Participants will need to bring their own laptops to actively engage in the hands-on exercises. The following should be installed in advance:
    • A web browser (Chrome or Firefox recommended).
    • Text editor (e.g., Visual Studio Code, Sublime Text) for code exploration.
    • Access to the internet for web-based tools and exercises.
  • All other necessary tools and instructions will be provided during the workshop.
session.longAbstract:
What You’ll Learn:
This workshop will provide an in-depth exploration of ADR, covering:
  • Understanding ADR & Its Role in Application Security – What makes ADR different from traditional security solutions like firewalls, and WAFs? How does it work in real-time threat detection?
  • Common Attack Vectors & How ADR Stops Them – Learn how threats like zero-day exploits, supply chain attacks, and runtime injections can bypass conventional defenses and how ADR can detect and respond effectively.
  • Live Demo: ADR in Action – Witness how ADR tools identify and mitigate threats in real-world attack scenarios. This hands-on demonstration will show how vulnerabilities are detected and the incredible context that ADR can provide you to contextualize and respond efficiently
  • Best Practices for Implementing ADR in Your Organization – Learn how to integrate ADR into your security stack, optimize response strategies, and minimize incident response times.
  • Case Studies & Lessons from the Field – Explore real-world examples of ADR preventing attacks, from small-scale application breaches to large-scale enterprise threats.


Who Should Attend?
This workshop is designed for:
  • Developers & DevOps Teams – Learn how to build security into your applications without compromising performance.
  • Security Engineers & SOC Analysts – Get hands-on experience in real-time threat detection and response within applications.
  • IT & Security Decision-Makers – Understand how ADR enhances overall cybersecurity posture and protects against modern attack techniques.

Why Attend?
With cyber threats becoming more sophisticated, traditional security measures are no longer enough. ADR offers a proactive, application-centric approach to security, ensuring that threats are detected before they cause damage. By attending this workshop, you’ll gain the knowledge and skills needed to stay ahead of attackers, protect your applications, and strengthen your cybersecurity defenses.
